articles.headline: Guilty Verdict for a Tycoon, and Russia
articles.snippet: The Kremlin’s continued prosecution of the Russian tycoon Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky is connected to the damaged investment climate in the country.
articles.abstract: The Kremlin’s continued prosecution of the Russian tycoon Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky is connected to the damaged investment climate in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: It took most of the week for Judge Viktor Danilkin to deliver the sentence against Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former Russian tycoon.

articles.headline: Iraq Moves to Ban Toy Guns as Play Turns Real
articles.snippet: The Health Ministry is concentrating on a cheap plastic air pistol that has caused hundreds of eye injuries in Iraq.
articles.abstract: The Health Ministry is concentrating on a cheap plastic air pistol that has caused hundreds of eye injuries in Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The Ministry of Health here is campaigning to ban the sale of guns in Iraq. Toy guns, that is.

articles.headline: In Ivory Coast, Bid to Ease Out Defiant Leader
articles.snippet: Laurent Gbagbo mocked the calls for him to step aside, while the United States said he was running out of time to take an offer to leave peacefully.
articles.abstract: Laurent Gbagbo mocked the calls for him to step aside, while the United States said he was running out of time to take an offer to leave peacefully.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Laurent Gbagbo vowed Friday that he would not cede power in Ivory Coast, while Obama administration officials warned that he was running out of time to accept an offer they had made to help him leave the country peacefully.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Political Battle on Illegal Immigration Shifts to States
articles.snippet: Legislators in at least six states said they would propose bills similar to Arizona’s law to fight illegal immigration.
articles.abstract: Legislators in at least six states said they would propose bills similar to Arizona’s law to fight illegal immigration.
articles.lead_paragraph: Legislative leaders in at least half a dozen states say they will propose bills similar to a controversial law to fight illegal immigration that was adopted by Arizona last spring, even though a federal court has suspended central provisions of that statute.

articles.headline: Boomers Hit New Self-Absorption Milestone: Age 65
articles.snippet: On New Year’s Day, the Baby Boom Generation’s oldest reach birthdays fraught with sociological significance.
articles.abstract: On New Year’s Day, the Baby Boom Generation’s oldest reach birthdays fraught with sociological significance.
articles.lead_paragraph: In keeping with a generation’s fascination with itself, the time has come to note the passing of another milestone: On New Year’s Day, the oldest members of the Baby Boom Generation will turn 65, the age once linked to retirement, early bird specials and gray Velcro shoes that go with everything.

articles.headline: The New Speed of Money, Reshaping Markets
articles.snippet: Machines have largely taken over stock market trading, creating a new technological order affecting nearly everyone who owns shares of stock or mutual funds.
articles.abstract: Machines have largely taken over stock market trading, creating a new technological order affecting nearly everyone who owns shares of stock or mutual funds.

articles.headline: Coupons for Patients, but Higher Bills for Insurers
articles.snippet: In their fight against generics, big pharmaceutical companies are covering part of patients’ co-payment for their drugs. But insurers say the practice raises the overall cost of care.
articles.abstract: In their fight against generics, big pharmaceutical companies are covering part of patients’ co-payment for their drugs. But insurers say the practice raises the overall cost of care.
articles.lead_paragraph: EXECUTIVES of a small insurance company in Albany were mystified when, almost overnight, its payments for a certain class of antibiotics nearly doubled, threatening to add about a half-million dollars annually in costs.

articles.headline: Public Workers Face Outrage as Budget Crises Grow
articles.snippet: Across the nation, irritation with public employee unions is palpable as state, city and town budgets suffer.
articles.abstract: Across the nation, irritation with public employee unions is palpable as state, city and town budgets suffer.
articles.lead_paragraph: FLEMINGTON, N.J. — Ever since Marie Corfield’s confrontation with Gov. Chris Christie this fall over the state’s education cuts became a YouTube classic, she has received a stream of vituperative e-mails and Facebook postings.

articles.headline: Several Warnings, Then a Soldier’s Lonely Death
articles.snippet: Many questions remain about Staff Sgt. David Senft’s death and whether the Army could have prevented it.
articles.abstract: Many questions remain about Staff Sgt. David Senft’s death and whether the Army could have prevented it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A gentle snow fell on the funeral of Staff Sgt. David Senft at Arlington National Cemetery on Dec. 16, when his bitterly divided California family came together to say goodbye. His 5-year-old son received a flag from a grateful nation.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Newcomers Set Out to Undo Obama Victories
articles.snippet: House Republicans plan to make good on a campaign vow: voting to repeal President Obama’s health care overhaul.
articles.abstract: House Republicans plan to make good on a campaign vow: voting to repeal President Obama’s health care overhaul.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Soon after the 112th Congress convenes Wednesday, Republicans in the House plan to make good on a campaign promise that helped vault many new members to victory: voting to repeal President Obama’s health care overhaul.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Diplomats Help Push Sales of Jetliners on the Global Market
articles.snippet: Sales campaigns for commercial jets on the global market often include politicking and cajoling at the highest levels of government.
articles.abstract: Sales campaigns for commercial jets on the global market often include politicking and cajoling at the highest levels of government.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Eric Lipton, Nicola Clark and Andrew W. Lehren and was written by Mr. Lipton.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton, Nicola Clark and Andrew W. Lehren

articles.headline: Japan Keeps a High Wall for Foreign Labor
articles.snippet: Immigration provides one remedy to Japan’s lethargic economy, but Tokyo is resisting accepting young workers.
articles.abstract: Immigration provides one remedy to Japan’s lethargic economy, but Tokyo is resisting accepting young workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: KASHIWA, Japan — Maria Fransiska, a young, hard-working nurse from Indonesia, is just the kind of worker Japan would seem to need to replenish its aging work force.

articles.headline: 3-D Wrinkle for Portable Gaming
articles.snippet: Portable devices are less necessary for gamers with smartphones, but gadget makers intend a comeback, with Nintendo using three-dimensional graphics.
articles.abstract: Portable devices are less necessary for gamers with smartphones, but gadget makers intend a comeback, with Nintendo using three-dimensional graphics.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Columbia Pictures Hopes to End Oscar Drought
articles.snippet: If “The Social Network” wins, the movie about the Facebook co-founder Mark Zuckerberg will end some 23 years of Columbia going without top honors on Academy Awards night.
articles.abstract: If “The Social Network” wins, the movie about the Facebook co-founder Mark Zuckerberg will end some 23 years of Columbia going without top honors on Academy Awards night.

articles.headline: TV Viewing Continues to Edge Up
articles.snippet: Americans watched more television than ever in 2010, according to the Nielsen Company, and the generation-long shift to cable from broadcast continued.
articles.abstract: Americans watched more television than ever in 2010, according to the Nielsen Company, and the generation-long shift to cable from broadcast continued.
articles.lead_paragraph: Historians may someday note with wonder that by the end of 2010, at least six cable television shows were about auctioneers and pawnbrokers. And all were considered successes by their respective channels.

articles.headline: The Great Mashup of 2011
articles.snippet: As the media landscape continues to change, a look at some of the developments that will make news in the coming year.
articles.abstract: As the media landscape continues to change, a look at some of the developments that will make news in the coming year.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, those of us who toiled in the backwater of media reporting  covering people who cover other people  were left to trace the slow-motion decline of mainstream media and the inconsequential pratfalls of nascent digital efforts.

articles.headline: Facing Threat From WikiLeaks, Bank Plays Defense
articles.snippet: Since WikiLeaks threatened to “take down” a major American bank, Bank of America has been hunting for signs that its systems have been compromised.
articles.abstract: Since WikiLeaks threatened to “take down” a major American bank, Bank of America has been hunting for signs that its systems have been compromised.
articles.lead_paragraph: By the time the conference call ended, it was nearly midnight at Bank of America’s headquarters in Charlotte, N.C., but the bank’s counterespionage work was only just beginning.

articles.headline: Rivals to the iPad Say This Is the Year
articles.snippet: This year, having digested the iPad’s victories and stumbles, manufacturers may just put out more of those tablets.
articles.abstract: This year, having digested the iPad’s victories and stumbles, manufacturers may just put out more of those tablets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Welcome to the year of the tablet. Again.
